Text_Numeracy: It was one of those days when I felt really good, and I decided to have a bit of real fun. The garage door was ajar, so I hopped on my motorcycle and took off around the neighborhood at a pretty good speed -- way over the roughly 25mph speed limit. Then I turned on to a short cul-de-sac, this road had an abrupt ending as it curved to the right. Without thinking, I decided to take the 90° turn at speed. In the previous 10-12' of the road, I had been going 40-45 mph; at the point of no return, I was going about 35mph. I wasn't able to make the turn. I hit the curb and flipped over. I went waay up, fell on my back, and somersaulted forward. As the motorcycle and my leg followed, my foot slammed sideways into the curb. My leg hurt really bad, but I knew from previous experience that pain does not necessarily equal serious injury, so I decided to try to walk home and pop my leg back into alignment. I took 2 steps, and the pain was so bad, I almost dropped to the ground. I decided to have someone on the cul-de-sac give me a ride home

Text_Numeracy: During my nursing clinical experience in nursing school, I had a patient that was a 50 yo female with type II diabetes. Her blood glucose level was in the 400s and she was in DKA. DKA is a complication of diabetes that is very dangerous and can be fatal. I knew that she needed a lot of insulin and IV fluids. Her nurse called the doctor for orders and was prescribed a large bolus of insulin and a large amount of IV fluids. It was a great experience because it demonstrated my knowledge of diabetes and DKA in the real world.

Text_Numeracy: One significant experience that demonstrated my knowledge of health and medical issues was when I had to manage my medication regimen. I also sought advice from pharmacists and used a pill organizer to ensure I took them correctly. This experience not only deepened my understanding of the importance of adherence to medication but also highlighted the complexities involved in managing health conditions. It reinforced my belief in the need for better access to healthcare professionals, even though I currently do not have a primary care physician.

Text_Numeracy: One significant experience that demonstrated my knowledge of health and medical issues was during a conversation with a close friend who was struggling to manage their medication regimen. I noticed they were feeling overwhelmed and confused about the dosages and timing of their prescriptions, which prompted me to share my own organization strategies. I explained how I use a pill organizer and set reminders on my phone for when to take my medications. I also emphasized the importance of regularly checking in with a healthcare professional and keeping an open line of communication. This interaction not only highlighted my understanding of medication management but also reinforced my commitment to living in the best possible health.
Text_Anxiety: I don’t feel much anxiety when meeting doctors. My primary concern is usually around ensuring that they understand my medication regimen and any potential interactions. Since I take multiple prescription drugs regularly, I'm always eager to discuss my health actively. I also tend to focus on the outcomes of these visits and how best to maintain my health, which helps keep anxieties at bay. Overall, I'm more interested in maintaining my active lifestyle and staying on top of my well-being than feeling nervous about the appointment itself.
Text_TrustPhys: I don’t have a primary care physician, so I approach doctors with a sense of caution rather than outright distrust. While I appreciate their expertise and the role they play in managing health, I often feel that the focus tends to be on quick consultations rather than holistic care. I prioritize living in the best possible health, so I seek out specialists who align with my active lifestyle and can cater to my specific needs more effectively. Trust can be built through consistent, personalized attention, which I find is often lacking in a general practice setting.
Text_SubjectiveLit: I feel I have a strong capacity to obtain, process, and understand basic health information and services, especially given my commitment to living in the best possible health. My regular engagement with healthcare professionals, despite not having a primary care physician, allows me to gather a wide range of insights and information regarding my medications and general health. Additionally, my active lifestyle and emphasis on physical activity further reinforce my ability to comprehend health information relevant to maintaining my well-being. Overall, I believe I am equipped to make appropriate health decisions based on the information available to me.
